factoid: Pierre reached the large house near the Horse Guards’ barracks.
Anatole lived in that large house.
Pierre entered the lighted porch of the house.
Pierre ascended the stairs of the house.
Pierre entered the house through the open door.
The anteroom of the house was empty.
Empty bottles were lying about in the anteroom.
Cloaks were lying about in the anteroom.
Overshoes were lying about in the anteroom.
There was a smell of alcohol in the anteroom.
Sounds of voices and shouting were heard in the distance from the anteroom.
Cards had been played in the house.
Supper had been served in the house.
The visitors had not yet dispersed after supper.
Pierre threw off his cloak.
Pierre entered the first room of the house.
Remains of supper were in the first room.
A footman was drinking secretly from the remaining glasses in the first room.
The footman believed that no one saw him.
Sounds of laughter came from the third room.
Shouting of familiar voices came from the third room.
Growling of a bear came from the third room.
General commotion came from the third room.
Eight or nine young men crowded anxiously around an open window in the third room.
Three young men were romping with a young bear.
One of those men was pulling the bear by the chain.
That man was trying to set the bear at the others.
One young man shouted that he bet a hundred on Stevens.
Another young man shouted that no one should hold on.
A third young man shouted that he bet on Dólokhov.
The same third young man told Kurágin to part their hands.
A young man told someone to leave Bruin alone and offered a bet.
A fourth young man shouted that at one draught, or he loses.
The host shouted Jacob to bring a bottle.
The host was a tall, handsome fellow.
The host stood in the midst of the group.
The host did not wear a coat.
The host had his fine linen shirt unfastened in front.
The host addressed Pierre.
The host said "Here is Pétya! Good man!" to Pierre.
A man of medium height with clear blue eyes cried from the window.
The voice was sober among drunken voices.
The man cried "Come here; part the bets!" from the window.
The man was Dólokhov.
Dólokhov was an officer of the Semënov regiment.
Dólokhov was a notorious gambler.
Dólokhov was a duelist.
Dólokhov lived with Anatole.
Pierre smiled.
Pierre looked around Dólokhov merrily.
Pierre said he did not understand.
Pierre asked what it was all about.
Anatole said to Pierre that he was not drunk yet.
Anatole said to Pierre to wait a bit.
Anatole said to Pierre to get a bottle.
Anatole took a glass from the table.
Anatole went up to Pierre.
Anatole told Pierre that he must drink first.
Pierre drank one glass after another.
Pierre looked from under his brows at the tipsy guests.
The tipsy guests were crowding around the window.
Pierre listened to the chatter of the guests.
Anatole kept refilling Pierre’s glass.
Dólokhov was betting with Stevens.
Stevens was an English naval officer.
Dólokhov bet that he would drink a bottle of rum.
The bottle of rum was sitting on the outer ledge of the third floor window.
Dólokhov's legs were hanging out on the outer ledge.
Anatole told Pierre to drink it all.
Anatole gave Pierre the last glass.
Anatole threatened that he would not let Pierre go if he did not drink.
Pierre said he would not.
Pierre pushed Anatole aside.
Pierre went up to the window.
Dólokhov held the Englishman’s hand.
Dólokhov repeated the terms of the bet clearly.
Dólokhov addressed Anatole and Pierre.
Dólokhov was of medium height.
Dólokhov had curly hair.
Dólokhov had light-blue eyes.
Dólokhov was about twenty-five years old.
Dólokhov wore no mustache.
Dólokhov's mouth was clearly visible.
Dólokhov's mouth had finely curved lines.
Dólokhov's upper lip formed a sharp wedge.
Dólokhov's lower lip closed firmly on the upper lip.
Dólokhov had two distinct smiles around the corners of his mouth.
Dólokhov had resolute, insolent intelligence in his eyes.
Dólokhov's face was striking.
Dólokhov was a man of small means.
Dólokhov had no connections.
Dólokhov lived with Anatole.
Dólokhov had a footing that earned respect from those who knew them.
Anatole spent tens of thousands of rubles.
Dólokhov nearly always won at games.
Dólokhov never lost clearheadedness regardless of how much he drank.
Kúrágin was notorious among the rakes and scapegraces of Petersburg.
Dólokhov was notorious among the rakes and scapegraces of Petersburg.
The bottle of rum was brought into the house.
The window frame prevented anyone from sitting on the outer sill.
Two footmen were forcing out the window frame.
The footmen were flurried.
The footmen were intimidated by the directions and shouts of the gentlemen.
Anatole strode up to the window with a swaggering air.
Anatole wanted to smash something.
Anatole pushed away the footmen.
Anatole tugged at the window frame.
Anatole could not move the window frame.
Anatole smashed a pane of the window.
